headline.main: When a Windfall of Money Arrives, So Can Challenges

docs.lead_paragraph: 7:35 a.m. | Updated Exuberance made a comeback this year at Josh Koplewicz's annual Halloween party. More than 1,000 people packed into a 6,000-square-foot space at the Good Units night club in Manhattan, a substantially larger crowd than in the last several years. The open bar was sponsored by Russian Standard vodka, and Mr. Koplewicz, an investment analyst at Goldman Sachs, was able to snag a big headliner: the hip-hop star Lil' Kim, who performed dressed in a black cat costume.

docs.lead_paragraph: The recent decision by the Obama administration to allow health insurance companies to continue to sell so-called mini-med policies, those plans that sharply limit coverage, remains controversial. The plans, which often cap benefits at just a few thousand dollars a year, do not comply with some of the new rules under the federal health care law.
docs.abstract: A Senate committee will take up the issue of limited health plans next week.
docs.snippet: A Senate committee will take up the issue of limited health plans next week.

docs.lead_paragraph: While not every Motown aficionado thinks Chris Clark got all the obscurity she deserved, there is other glue that binds. No one disputes that romanticizing the eat-or-get-eaten early days of the label's artists was a great act of myth building. Diana Ross's father got so tired of hearing what a rough childhood she had in Detroit's Brewster Projects, he told one of her biographers how nice the lawns and courtyards there were. "The apartment we were in had three bedrooms, a full basement, a living room, kitchen and dinette," Fred Ross said. "It wasn't so terrible at all, believe me."
docs.abstract: The Supreme singer created a sultry musical mini-genre whose compass points were halfway between the Motor City and Trinidad.
docs.snippet: The Supreme singer created a sultry musical mini-genre whose compass points were halfway between the Motor City and Trinidad.

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
